cards.front: What is the main goal of **Mitosis**?
cards.back: To produce two identical daughter cells for growth and tissue repair.

cards.front: What is the main goal of **Meiosis**?
cards.back: To produce four genetically different haploid gametes (sperm and egg cells) for sexual reproduction.
Diploid cells have two full sets of chromosomes (46 in humans); Haploid cells have only one set (23 in humans).
Pairs of chromosomes (one from each parent) that are the same size and contain the same types of genes.

cards.front: What is **Crossing Over** and when does it occur?
cards.back: The exchange of genetic material between homologous chromosomes during Prophase I of Meiosis; it creates genetic variation.
The random way homologous pairs line up during Metaphase I, ensuring that offspring have a unique mix of maternal and paternal genes.

cards.front: How many divisions occur in Mitosis vs. Meiosis?
cards.back: Mitosis has one division (PMAT); Meiosis has two successive divisions (PMAT I and PMAT II).
Body cells (like skin or muscle cells) that are diploid and produced through mitosis.
The diploid cell formed when a haploid sperm cell fertilizes a haploid egg cell.

cards.front: What happens during **Anaphase I** of Meiosis?
cards.back: Homologous pairs are pulled apart toward opposite poles (unlike Mitosis, where sister chromatids are pulled apart).
An error in Meiosis where chromosomes fail to separate properly, resulting in gametes with too many or too few chromosomes.
Two identical copies of a single replicated chromosome that are joined together at the centromere.

cards.front: Why is **genetic variation** important for a species?
cards.back: It increases the chances that some individuals will survive if the environment changes, preventing extinction.
Another name for Meiosis I, because it reduces the chromosome number from diploid to haploid.

cards.front: Does DNA replication happen between Meiosis I and Meiosis II?
cards.back: No. DNA is only replicated once (during Interphase) before the whole process begins.
